body:
Yeah, tick subdivision probably requires creating two additional major ticks outside the original ticks before doing the subdivision. This will require some thought.

In the meantime, I think in your case it might be cleaner to use axis.ticks(d3.time.days) and then use post-selection to do something special for the weeks.
Thank you for the suggestion, I never used post-selection, I will deepen the topic. About the idea of creating two additional major ticks, I can't see any drawback in it.

issue.title: Replace axis.tickSubdivide with axis.minorTicks. Fixes #1115.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
I’m not sure yet if this is a good idea, but it does seem more flexible than subdividing ticks in the axis that were computed by the scale. The problem with the simpler fix of #1115 is that the axis can’t force the scale to generate two extra major ticks—those ticks could be irregularly-spaced, as is the case with a time scale.

So, rather than trying to subdivide ticks uniformly, the axis exposes a way of creating minor ticks. For example, you could have major ticks using d3.time.weeks, and minor ticks using d3.time.days. Any minor tick that is also a major tick is only displayed as a major tick. 

One weakness with this approach is that it assumes there is a scale.ticks method, so there’s no way to create minor ticks for an ordinal scale or other scale that doesn’t support generating ticks. Likewise, although you can specify major ticks explicitly using axis.tickValues, I haven’t exposed an axis.minorTickValues method.

This pull request retains the axis.tickSubdivide method as a no-op, so that existing code will not break. However, this means you need to update code to call axis.minorTicks if you want minor ticks displayed. It’s possible in some cases to generate suitable minor tick arguments, and thus have better backwards-compatibility, but since it’s not possible in all cases this seems like a reasonable option. Alternatively we could defer this until 4.0?

Lastly, my other reservation is whether the axis needs an explicit concept of major and minor ticks at all. It seems like clients could specify only major ticks, and then use post-selection to mark a subset of them as minor ticks.

body:
I’ve been looking at this issue, and the problem is there is no way for the axis to create additional major ticks for the purpose of subdividing to create additional minor ticks. (Well, it might be possible to abuse scale.nice, but in general I like that the axis doesn’t need to know how the ticks were generated.) So, I’m considering two solutions:
- #1350 replaces axis.tickSubdivide with axis.minorTicks. It’s a similar idea, except because the scale generates both the major and minor ticks, you have more flexibility over where those minor ticks are placed (they need not be uniformly positioned between major ticks), and the scale will guarantee that the minor ticks cover the domain. I think this is a more intuitive and more explicit.
- #1351 goes one step further and removes axis.tickSubdivide with no replacement, since you can achieve the same result of creating minor ticks by simply [post-selecting the ticks](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/f2bedf50d1017f94a14d/66d95b225bd7d48c544df5bcbfcd9db4cfeee8e8). I like the simplicity of this approach, although sometimes it can be harder to remove functionality than to add it. :)

In either case, we can’t fix this in a patch release, so this will either be in 3.x or 4.0.

#1350 looks better to me. post selection is simple and works, but breaks the incapsulation of the axis component. for me it's natural that the d3 interface grows encapsulating the most common usage patterns, with the right flexibility

So, it might be useful for you to know what happened to me here.

When I updated to 3.3.0, `tickSubdivide` stopped working for me. I thought maybe it was a breaking change (although it did surprise me because it was just a minor release) so I went to check the docs to see if there was a change. I noticed that `tickSubdivide` is listed on the API page, but is _not_ listed on the axis docs. So I went to github issues and found this. I thought, ok fine, I can switch to `minorTicks`, but now I see that the docs don't have seem to have anything about `minorTicks`, so I'll have to dig into the code. All that said, I'd recommend that any breaking changes at least be well-documented for people who have a similar experience.
Ah, reading further, I see there's no replacement. Well, regardless, something about the removal of tickSubdivide in the docs would be beneficial.

I removed it from the docs because it was deprecated, and I delete deprecated APIs from the docs so that they aren’t distracting to newcomers. Although 3.3.0 removes the functionality from axis.tickSubdivide, the function still exists so the code is now a no-op, and that’s why it wasn’t considered a breaking change.
So, the best place to find where to replace the functionality is a github issue?

Deprecation notices are posted in the [release notes](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/releases/tag/v3.3.0) along with documentation on how to update to the new release. In this case, it is to use post-selection and multiple axes, per the [linked example](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/4349486).
Ah, sorry, release notes on github are still new to me. Thanks.
No worries. Thank you for the bug report!

Sorry for commenting in an old closed issue. Found this because http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/1166403 is linked from the first google result for 'd3 axis'.
Just wanted to say something that completely removes functionality should probably be considered a breaking change. If someone upgrades d3 and all the ticks disappear from their graph, that's a breakage. Even though it doesn't throw an error, it breaks apps
